Vacuum sealed it's sitting in the fridge now has to sit for a couple weeks so that the smoke flavor can mellow out
I used hickory. I probably would have used applewood but I didn't have any.

Think it's because you don't burn enough coals with an electric to produce the nitrites and nitrates needed to form a smoke ring. In the end, smoke ring does nothing for the taste of the meat. It's only a visual thing.
Yes post war laminate stock. Serials scrubbed and stamped matching during refurb.
Yes you need a cold smoker attachment or a pellet burner for the smoke. You don't heat the smoker or the cheese will melt

WRITING.TITLE: Poor man's burnt ends

WRITING.TEXT: I did originally post a description...don't know what happened to it. Rubbed chuck roast placed into fridge overnight then smoked to 185 IT. Remove from smoker and let rest 30 minutes. Cut into about 1" cubes and place into foil pan with more rub and enough BBQ sauce to just coat. Return to smoker for 2 more hours.
They're great make them all the time. They're called meat candy because they melt in your mouth
Smoked at 225. Chuck usually takes a good 12 hours. Go to an IT of 185, that is when you know it is ready to pull out and be cubed.
Never had the real deal from brisket but these are damn good.
I do it in my smoker @ 170 for about 6 hours or so depending on thickness and personal preference for doneness.
Done is subjective. I smoke mine @ 170 for about 6 hours but it depends on the thickness. Some pieces I have to pull earlier than others. They can end up getting too crispy and brittle.
Usually after a good 2 hours they are pretty much done. You can check one to see if it is tender enough, if not let them ride a little longer.
Getting there....about ready to hit the stall.
1942 91/30 Izhevsk arsenal in a post war stock. The most common year there is.
That's high for a common 1943 year like that. LGS are always going to be high.

WRITING.TITLE: A little too excited...

WRITING.TEXT: Been using an electric Masterbuilt for several years. Biggest tip I would say is to get an alternate pellet burner like an AMNPS tray or a WEDGIE and use that instead of the chip burner. They burn much longer and you won't be adding chips every hour or so. Additionally, they can be used for cold smoking which can't be done with the integrated chip burner because the unit needs to be on and heating to burn the chips and generate smoke.

WRITING.TITLE: What is the one thing that people do when they eat that drives you bat shit crazy?

WRITING.TEXT: Depending on which model you have. This is the one I use. I have a 30" Gen. 1 smoker and it fits nicely on the two bars to the left of the chip tray. http://www.amazenproducts.com/product_p/amnps5x8.htm I also have the WEDGIE which works great. Puts out more smoke but for a shorter period of time. http://www.thesmokinwedgie.com/index.php?option=com_ecwid amp;view=ecwid amp;Itemid=182#!/Smokin-Wedgie-Products-Stainless-Steel-Multi-Unit-Discounts/c/9268060/offset=0 amp;sort=normal

WRITING.TITLE: [Homemade] Best baked beans

WRITING.TEXT: 3 CANS OF PORK AND BEANS 1 GREEN BELL PEPPER 1 ONION 5 SLICES OF BACON 1/4 CUP OF BROWN SUGAR 1/4 cup of maple syrup Your favorite barbecue sauce DIRECTIONS Open, drain and rinse your pork and beans Pour into grill/ oven safe dish Chop onion and bell pepper into desired size add to beans Add brown sugar, maple syrup. Mix all ingredients together. Add barbecue sauce, I usually use 1/4 -1/2 cup depending on how saucy I want my beans that day. Place bacon slices over beans and place on grill (or in the oven at 375 degrees) Cook until bacon is done

Yes I have an AMNPS and a Wedgie
Haven't tried it yet. Usually let it rest a couple weeks.

Looks like the year has been ground off from what I can see...picture isn't that good of the barrel. Appears to be Izhevsk factory. Rifle is in a post war laminated stock. Most of the markings are unknown production/inspection stamps and generally not too much to get excited about. It has been refurbished, which is very common. Serial numbers have been force stamp matched during refurb, also very common.

Buffing out stamps wouldn't normally be done at refurb...not sure why that is the case with this one. Post war stocks have the brass, pressed in sling escutcheons. War time stocks have only a half metal liner in the front and nothing in the rear slot. Prewar stocks have screwed in escutcheons.

Because 99% of Mosins are. It's rare to have an all original matching rifle. Differences in the letter and number fonts are the first tell. During refurbishment all the parts were put into piles and good rifles were assembled together by grabbing good parts out of the piles. The parts came from any rifle from any arsenal or any year. http://www.russian-mosin-nagant.com/refurbishment/index.html
Looks great. Love a good Reuben
Looks refinished which generally affects value.

I use the tray and a Wedgie sometimes. It's best to pull out the chip loader an inch or two for air flow. Use a blowtorch to light it and let it burn a good 5 minutes before blowing it out. I just put the tray with pellets in the MES while it's warming up to remove any moisture.

WRITING.TITLE: 2nd brisket I've done.

WRITING.TEXT: 2nd brisket, better than my first, which was just a flat. Did a full 12 lb. packer this time. Wrapped in butcher paper at about 165. Point got to about 198 first, so I separated them and pulled the point and put it in a cooler. The flat took a couple hours longer. Amazing how moist and tasty the point is compared to the flat. Masterbuilt electric. Taste was awesome.

Don't strip the stock or you will ruin much of the value. Take it apart and clean all the cosmoline from the metal. I use brake cleaner to get it all off. There are many different ways to do it and everyone thinks theirs is the best.

Nice pre war Tula in a war time stock. You can Google markings but honestly the vast majority are typically unknown production/inspection stamps. 7.62x54r.net is a good resource to start looking at. Enjoy her.
Nice Finn Capture. The counterbore is no big deal, really means nothing other than it's a better shooter now than it was.
Very nice for your first one...do not screw with it. That is a real beauty.

An M39 is one of the best Mosin variants you can have. They will be more expensive than your standard 91/30. If you are just getting into them, the regular 91/30 may be more up your alley if price is a consideration.

WRITING.TITLE: Reverse sear question
WRITING.TEXT: I love reverse sear for thicker cuts. I'm wondering what everyone here does....Do you normally cook to IT first, THEN sear, or do you sear first, THEN cook to IT? I've seen it done both ways.
I use a pellet burner tray in my smoker. I have a Wedgie and an AMNPS tray. You could always apply the smoke with something like that.
How did you regulate the temp?
You don't need a smoker to use a small pellet burner tray. You can light pellets and put the tray in just about anything to add smoke.
You don't need a smoker to use a small pellet burner tray. You can light pellets and put the tray in just about anything to add smoke.

WRITING.TITLE: Dry brined T bone

WRITING.TEXT: Did a quick dry brine on a T bone - first time I have ever done one. Only left salt on for about an hour, then rinsed and only added fresh ground multi blend pepper. I must say it was one of the best steaks I have had.
I would reverse sear by doing them in the oven first until about 20 degrees below desired IT, then rest for 10 minutes, then searing on the grill.
Gets too salty for my taste, but that's me. It was salty enough for me as cooked. There was a good bit more salt than 1/4-1/2 tsp I had seen as recommended.

They are great, I love them so far. Only about 4 cooks in on them but everything seems juicier and more flavorful. The entire grate is basically acts like a grill flavorizer bar. The juices drop down and immediately vaporize and go right back on the meat.

WRITING.TITLE: Did 5 lbs. of cheese and 7 lbs. of bacon.

WRITING.TEXT: I normally do about 2 hours. Best way to see what you like it take some out after 1 hour, take more out after 1.5 hours and take some out after 2 hours (or whatever interval you think). mark them with "1 hour", "1.5 hours", "2 hours", then try them and see what you like best.
Yes you have to cold smoke cheese. I use either an AMNPS 5x8 tray or a Wedgie with pellets to cold smoke.

WRITING.TITLE: Awesome pic from 1971

WRITING.TEXT: By the end of September 1969, Alex Lifeson, John Rutsey and Geddy Lee had decided to regroup and once again use the name RUSH. The band performed as a three piece until February of 1971 when guitarist Mitch Bossi joined the band. The band reverted back to a three piece when Bossi left the band in May 1971 and has remained that way since.
